related.description: American students are bored by math, science and engineering. They buy smartphones and tablets by the millions but don't pursue the skills necessary to build them. Engineers and physicists are often portrayed as clueless geeks on television, and despite the high pay and the importance of such jobs to the country's future, the vast majority of high school graduates don't want to go after them.

title: Driving students to art school
content:
Academy of Art University has built an educational money machine.

How powerful a machine, the privately owned school won't say. Its 18,000 art students each pay about $20,000 a year, collectively adding up to an estimated $360 million in tuition. About a third of its students live in Academy-owned housing, according to the school, which operates dormitories at locations throughout the city. If 5,000 students pay $1,000 a month for housing, that's another $60 million in potential revenue, for an estimated total exceeding $400 million. It is one of the largest art schools in the country.

"Bigger is better for us," said President Elisa Stephens, the third generation to run the for-profit school founded by her grandfather. "It keeps tuition reasonably priced."

When she took over from her father in 1992, there were 3,500 students, Stephens said. In 20 years she has more than quintupled the enrollment and revenue.

"There is a way to run a school for profit," she said. "We just run it on tuition."

That its growth spurt coincided with the younger Stephens' arrival is probably no accident. Stephens is trained as a lawyer, but her true calling is marketing the Academy of Art and its programs.

She aims her pitch at high school students. "If you want to be a pro artist, you should get goin' because you can be young," Stephens said. "All the ideas are coming from 18- and 19-year-olds. When you are 30, you are old. When you are 40, you have to work at staying in the game. You can become old-fashioned."

Her marketing message carries urgency. "Clothes come out four times a year," Stephens said. "Cars come out every year. Movies are coming out all the time. TV commercials are changing all the time. Art is moving very fast."

James Dunn is a senior editor at the San Francisco Business Times. Major projects include editing technology and finance beats, and Best Places to Work.
